Math_Problem:
Let \(\mathbb{R}^{+}\) be the set of positive real numbers. Find all functions \(f:\mathbb{R}^{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{+}\) such that, for all \(x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{+}\),
\[f(xy + f(x)) = xf(y) + 2\] Instead of determining all positive real-valued functions on the positive reals that satisfy the given functional equation, simply find \(k = f(1) - 2\), where \(f(1)\) is the value at 1 of any such function. Determine all \(\alpha \in \mathbb{R}\) such that for every continuous function \(f:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), differentiable on \((k,1)\), with \(f(k)=k\) and \(f(1)=1\), there exists some \(\xi \in(k,1)\) such that \(f(\xi)+\alpha=f^{\prime}(\xi)\). Instead of determining all real numbers \(\alpha\) such that every function in the given class satisfies the existence condition on the derivative, simply find \(d = h(1) + 1\), where \(h\) is the function in the given class for which the difference between the derivative and the function value is constant. In the coordinate space of dimension \(d\) consider the set \(S\) of all points with integer coordinates. For a positive integer \(k\), two distinct points \(A\), \(B \in S\) will be called \(k\)-friends if there is a point \(C \in S\) such that the area of the triangle \(ABC\) is equal to \(k\). A set \(T \subset S\) will be called \(k\)-clique if every two points in \(T\) are \(k\)-friends. Find the least positive integer \(k\) for which there exists a \(k\)-clique with more than 200 elements.

Synthesised_By.A317: Let $\mathbb{R}^{+}$ be the set of positive real numbers. Find all functions $f:\mathbb{R}^{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{+}$ such that, for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$ , \[f(xy + f(x)) = xf(y) + 2\]

Synthesised_By.A552: Determine all \(\alpha \in \mathbb{R}\) such that for every continuous function \(f:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\), differentiable on \((0,1)\), with \(f(0)=0\) and \(f(1)=1\), there exists some \(\xi \in(0,1)\) such that \(f(\xi)+\alpha=f^{\prime}(\xi)\).

Synthesised_By.A4278:
In the coordinate plane consider the set $ S$ of all points with integer coordinates. For a positive integer $ k$, two distinct points $A$, $ B\in S$ will be called $ k$-[i]friends[/i] if there is a point $ C\in S$ such that the area of the triangle $ ABC$ is equal to $ k$. A set $ T\subset S$ will be called $ k$-[i]clique[/i] if every two points in $ T$ are $ k$-friends. Find the least positive integer $ k$ for which there exits a $ k$-clique with more than 200 elements.

[i]
